On Sun, 13 Apr 2003 20:47:02 -0000, "javainsel" <javainsel@...>
said:
> This message only has an HTML part -- this is a text generated
> representation
> 
> 
>    1. We separate the test cases in an own package. Is that best
>    practice?

It's generally a matter of taste, except...

>    2. When doing this, some methods with default (package) visiblilty
>    cannot be accessed. But when using the Reflection API, this methods
>    can be accessed. Is it okay to use the reflection? Or is it bad
>    style?

... when your public API has the benefit of being package private, I
think it makes sense to put tests in the same package structure.  That
doesn't mean they have to live in the same physical directory though. 
You could group tests in their own top level directory and prod. code in
its own.  With this you can keep the same exact package structures in
both but tests don't get mixed into prod. code, if that matters to you.

>    3. What about testing private methods? It is normally not possible
>    if the test is in an own class. But again I can use the reflection
>    to acess private methods. Should I do that? Or should I only test
>    methods with public access?
>    Maybe this question has been asked. But I have problems
>    understanding the nature of the search results in this forum.

In general, I think testing private methods is really a violation of the
object.  If you are testing its public API (note the answer to #2), you
are really testing everything under the covers vicariously.  This gives
you the freedom of keeping the API but changing the implementation.
